nodes.text: BinFI can efficiently identify safety-critical bits in machine learning systems by leveraging the (approximate) monotonicity of ML error-propagation functions and a binary-search-like fault injection strategy

Many common ML computations (convolution, matmul, ReLU, pooling, batch norm, SoftMax, data transforms) are monotonic or approximately monotonic, so their composite error-propagation (EP) function is often monotonic or approximately monotonic

BinFI: a binary-search-like fault injection algorithm that bisects bit significance (separately for 0-bits and 1-bits) to find an SDC-boundary bit where higher-order bit flips cause SDCs and lower-order flips are masked
Implemented BinFI by extending the TensorFI fault-injection tool to support DNN operators and three injection modes: exhaustive, random, and binary FI
BinFI identified 99.56% of safety-critical bits with 99.63% precision across evaluated benchmarks (high recall and precision across steering, traffic sign, and image classification models)
BinFI requires about 20% of the fault-injection trials of exhaustive FI (roughly a 5x speedup), since binary search grows logarithmically with bitwidth
BinFI estimates overall silent data corruption (SDC) probability closely to exhaustive FI (ground truth), often with near-zero deviation for models with monotonic EP

Random fault injection has poor coverage for finding safety-critical bits (even when matching BinFI trials random FI finds only about 19% of critical bits; at exhaustive-level trials random FI still finds <65%)

Fault model and assumptions: single-fault-per-execution, faults mapped to operator outputs in TensorFlow graphs, main memory/cache/register file assumed protected by ECC/parity, faults originate in processor data path, consider inference phase only

Limitation: approximate monotonicity can cause BinFI to miss a small fraction of critical bits (observed miss proportion <0.5% in evaluation) because EP non-monotonic segments may violate the search ordering
BinFI performance scales with datatype bitwidth: the number of trials grows logarithmically with bitwidth and recall/precision remain high across 16-, 32-, and 64-bit representations

BinFI is applicable to safety-critical ML deployed in autonomous vehicles and other HPC ML domains (medical, scientific ML), enabling selective protection strategies informed by identified critical bits

Evaluation methodology: extended TensorFI (TensorFI-BinaryFI) tested on 8 ML models and 6 datasets (including driving frames, traffic signs, MNIST, CIFAR-10, ImageNet variants); exhaustive FI used as ground truth; comparisons to random FI and exhaustive FI

Conclusion: BinFI provides a practical trade-off—very high coverage and accuracy in identifying safety-critical bits with substantially lower overhead than exhaustive FI—making it useful to guide low-cost selective protection of ML systems
